BC-SCIENCE-TIMES-BUDGET-NYT 
   The New York Times News Service plans the following    Science
Times    stories for papers of Tuesday, March 14:

   SCI-EVOLUTIONARY-PSYCHOLOGY (Undated) _ When two scientists
proposed in a recent book that rape was best viewed as a sexual act
with its roots in evolution, it set off a squall of protest from
feminists and social scientists, won the researchers appearances on
shows like NBC's ``Dateline,'' and became the talk of the cocktail
party circuit. Even last week the controversy continued, with the
book's authors conducting a rancorous exchange over a scathing
review in the scientific journal Nature. But the case put forward
was not, as some assumed, a fringe theory developed by a pair of
renegade researchers. Rather, the arguments fit into a larger
theoretical framework, the work of a group of scientists who have
ushered Darwin into new and provocative areas, including sexual
attraction between men and women, parenting, jealousy and violence,
as well as less touchy regions like the learning of language and
the organization of perception. By Erica Goode. (3500 words)

   With photo.

   SCI-MARS-NASA (Undated) _ NASA on Monday issued its findings on
the Mars orbiter that was lost and on its ``faster, cheaper,
better'' strategy that has come under some criticism. By Warren E.
Leary. (800 words)  

   SCI-MARS-GEOLOGY (Undated) _ The Mars Global Surveyor, which
keeps orbiting the planet 12 times a day, is giving scientists a
clearer and more intriguing view of the planet's geology. By John
Noble Wilford. (725 words)

   With photos, NYT1,2

   SCI-MOON-METEORITES (Undated) _ Fresh analysis of moon dirt, or
regolith, has raised speculation that an upsurge of meteorite
bombardment could have contributed to the emergence of complex
lifeforms with diverse anatomical designs. By dating glass beads in
the lunar soil provided striking evidence that meteors had been
creating craters at a higher rate over the last 400 million years.
By John Noble Wilford. (1225 words)

   SCI-EXTINCTION-HOTSPOTS (Undated) _ Once ecosystems lose key
species, they are not likely to recover their full function and
biotic variety in less than about 10 million years, according to a
new analysis. But other scientists say that there may be a
practical way to stem the tide of extinction markedly: by
concentrating conservation efforts and funds on a relatively small
number of highly vulnerable ``hotspots'' around the world that each
contain a large concentration of species found nowhere else. By
William K. Stevens. (640 words)

   SCI-WOLVES-RESURGENT (Undated) _ On the brink of extinction just
a few years ago, wolves are thriving in many areas around the
world, often to the delight of city dwelling conservations but to
the chagrin of farmers. By David Binder. (1250 words)

   SCI-POLLUTION-CLIMATE (Undated) _ New findings on aerosols,
microscopic particles of atmospheric dust, sea salt and smoke,
confirm scientists' suspicions: The flood of aerosols loosed by
urban and industrial pollution suppresses rainfall and snowfall
downwind of the pollution source. In the process, clouds become
brighter, reflecting more sunlight. They may also stay around
longer, and the combined effect is to exert extra cooling on
localities and regions underneath those particular clouds.. By
William K. Stevens. (900 words)

   SCI-DISCOVERY-HYPE (Undated) _ Too often, scientific discoveries
are forced into hype to grasp the public interest. In truth, most
developments are incremental. An essay by Lawrence M. Krauss. (1060
words)

   SCI-WATCH (Undated) _ News and notes on science: Items on a
microbe that thrives on acid, how decor affects pollution in a home
and how solar flares can interfere with spacecraft and radio
transmissions. By Henry Fountain. (675 words)

   SCI-BRAIN-LOCATIONS (Undated) _ A scientific technique called
functional magnetic resonance imaging, or FMRI, is finding precise
brain locations related to all sorts of human traits and
activities. Among them are hyperactivity centers in children, cells
that specialize in the naming of fruits and a even spot in the
brain that lights up when a man is sexually aroused. By Sandra
Blakeslee. (1530 words)

   SCI-COLON-CANCER (Undated) _ Cases column. A simple but invasive
procedure can help doctors catch colon cancer early (or even in
preliminary stages), but many people, especially men, are put off
by the process. By Richard M. Cohen. (1250 words)

   SCI-INFECTIONS-HOME (Undated) _ As health care moves
increasingly from the hospital to the living room, infection, the
bane of the medical institution, is moving with it. By Eric
Nagourney. (750 words)

   SCI-MIGRAINE (Undated) _ Many Americans fail to take advantage
of current treatments available for migraine headaches, new
literature shows. By Keith Mulvihill. (1050 words)

   SCI-BRODY-HEALTH (Undated) _ Personal Health column: Despite the
extensive reorganization of medical care that this country has
witnessed in recent years, the health maintenance organization
remains penny wise and pound foolish. And the consumer are paying
the price, with health and pocketbook. By Jane E. Brody. (1230
words)

   SCI-VITAL-SIGNS (Undated) _ News and notes on health and
fitness:

   _ When a heart-attack victim is rushed to the emergency room,
chances are that among the array of treatments doctors administer
will be one of the drugs known as clot-busters. But in many of
those cases, because doctors have to make crucial dosage decisions
on the fly, the drugs may be doing more harm than good, a new study
has found. 315 words.

   _ A common heart condition, irregular heartbeat, which under
normal condition poses little problem, may have more serious
consequences if a heart attack strikes. 155 words.

   _ Neurologists are reporting several cases where a small,
tumorlike mass can cause people to feel like they have to laugh.
The patients, whose conditions were described in a recent issue of
the journal Neurology, said that the sensation was not unpleasant,
but that it could be unnerving. 205 words.

   _ It is no secret that serious credit card debt is bad for one's
financial health, but it could also be bad for physical health.
Sociologists writing in the journal Social Science & Medicine say
they have found evidence that people who owe money on their credit
cards tend to be in poorer health. 290 words.

   _ On paper, the instructions for someone facing a barium enema
exam are not very complicated: follow the diet guidelines and take
the medicine to help empty the lower intestine. The procedure is
straightforward. But for many patients, doctors say, the first
hurdle is not the enema itself but the instructions, which many
people cannot fully understand them. 225 words.

   SCI-Q&A (Undated) _ A science question answered: Why don't the
eyes freeze up? By C. Claiborne Ray. (300 words)

   Photos, where indicated, are being sent to NYT photo clients.
Graphics, to NYT graphic clients. Non-subscribers can make
individual purchase by calling (888) 603-1036 or (212) 556-4204.

   Some ScienceTimes stories are available to international clients
only by special arrangement, and are so marked. Asian and European
points: contact Karl Horwitz in Paris for details and prices
(Phone: 47 42 17 11; FAX: 47-42-80-44).
